That is, it prints the commit HEAD points to, then its parent, its parent, and so on. It traverses back through the repoâ€™s ancestry, by recursively looking up each commitâ€™s parent. (In practice, some commits have more than one parent. To see a more representative log, use a command like git log â€“oneline â€“graph â€“decorate.) git reflog doesnâ€™t traverse HEADâ€™s ancestry at all. The reflog is an ordered list of the commits that HEAD has pointed to: itâ€™s undo history for your repo. The reflog isnâ€™t part of the repo itself (itâ€™s stored separately to the commits themselves) and isnâ€™t included in pushes, fetches or clones; itâ€™s purely local. Aside: understanding the reflog means you canâ€™t really lose data from your repo once itâ€™s been committed. If you accidentally reset to an older commit, or rebase wrongly, or any other operation that visually â€œremovesâ€ commits, you can use the reflog to see where you were before and git reset â€“hard back to that ref to restore your previous state.
